newsitem.title: USA: NFL AMERICAN FOOTBALL-JAGUARS UPSET BILLS, COWBOYS ROMP PAST VIKINGS.
newsitem.headline: NFL AMERICAN FOOTBALL-JAGUARS UPSET BILLS, COWBOYS ROMP PAST VIKINGS.

text.p: The precocious Jacksonville Jaguars upset the Buffalo Bills 30-27 and the defending champion Dallas Cowboys romped past the Minnesota Vikings 40-15 on the opening day of NFL playoffs Saturday.

Natrone Means rushed for 175 yards and Mike Hollis kicked three field goals, including a 45-yard game-winner with 3:07 remaining, as the second-year Jaguars triumphed in their first-ever playoff appearance and dealt the Bills their first loss in 10 playoff games at Rich Stadium.
"It feels great," said Means, who had 31 carries. "The offensive line did a great job all day long. Once we settled down, we played our type of ball."
"Natrone was a huge force today," said Jaguars coach Tom Coughlin.
Hollis's game-winner bounced off the right pole but still went through as Jacksonville (10-7) beat Buffalo (10-7) in an AFC wild-card game, the first meeting between the two teams.
Jacksonville will play either Denver (13-3) or New England (11-5) in the second round of the AFC playoffs next weekend.

It appeared the Bills, in their eighth playoff appearance in nine years, were headed to victory when Jeff Burris picked off a tipped pass and returned it 38 yards for a touchdown 43 seconds into the fourth quarter to snap a 20-20 tie.
"At the moment it made an impact but they came back and did what they had to do," said Burris.

The Jaguars produced a 10-play, 65-yard drive capped by a two-yard touchdown pass from Mark Brunell, who completed 18-of-33 passes for 239 yards with two interceptions, to Jimmy Smith. That tied the game at 27-27 with 8:40 remaining.
"Give Jacksonville credit," said Buffalo coach Marv Levy. "They were down by seven in the fourth quarter and went the length of the field for a TD and then got the field goal."

On Buffalo's next possession, quarterback Jim Kelly fumbled after being hit by safety Chris Hudson. The ball was recovered by cornerback Aaron Beasley at the Jacksonville 41-yard line. Kelly was knocked out of the game on the play.
The Jaguars then drove 31 yards in eight plays to set up Hollis's winning field goal.

Todd Collins replaced Kelly on Buffalo's final two possessions. Tony Brackens sacked Collins and forced a fumble and linebacker Eddie Robinson recovered the ball deep in Buffalo territory with 11 seconds left to seal the win.
Kelly completed 21-of-32 passes for 239 yards with an interception. Collins was 1-of-4 for seven yards.

In the key matchup of the game, second-year left tackle Tony Boselli held Bills perennial All-Pro defensive end Bruce Smith without a sack. Smith led the AFC with 13 1/2 sacks in 1996 while Boselli, the second overall pick in the 1995 draft, allowed just one sack this season.

"Bruce Smith is a great player. I knew I didn't have to play perfect, I just had to play hard," said Boselli. "I thank God for giving me that confidence and the ability to do it. The only thing I was worried about was keeping my poise."
"He did a pretty good job," said Smith. "I think they had a very good blocking scheme. It wasn't like he was one-on-one all day. I give him credit."

In Irving, Texas, George Teague forced two fumbles -- one of which prevented a touchdown -- and returned an interception 29 yards for a score as the Cowboys embarrassed the Vikings in an NFC wild-card game.

Troy Aikman, Emmitt Smith, Michael Irvin and Deion Sanders all had big games for the Cowboys (11-6), who despite winning a fifth straight NFC East Division title were relegated to the wild-card round for the first time since 1991.

The Cowboys next will face the Carolina Panthers, the NFC West champions but a second-year team that will be playing the first post-season game in franchise history. Dallas has reached the NFC Championship four straight years, winning the Super Bowl three times during that span.
With quarterback Brad Johnson making his first playoff start, the Vikings never got untracked. They committed four turnovers and allowed 268 yards in the first half, falling behind 30-0.
Minnesota (9-8) lost its playoff opener for the fourth time in four appearances under coach Dennis Green. The Vikings have lost seven straight post-season games since 1988.

Smith ran for 116 yards on 17 carries and had four recpetions for 26 yards. "This is the best I have felt all year," said Smith, who sat out last week's game against the Redskins. "I had a lot of spring in my legs."

Aikman scored on a 2-yard run and went 19-for-29 passing for 178 yards with one interception before yielding to Jason Garrett after the game was in hand. Irvin had eight catches for 103 yards. Sanders had a fumble recovery and an interception.
But the key play came when Teague punched the ball out of Amp Lee's arms as he was about to score a game-tying touchdown.
"I have never felt this way in the NFL," said Teague. "Stripping the ball was the only way to stop Lee from scoring. I took a chance. If I tackle him he falls over the goal line."

"It changed the game when they stripped the ball from Amp Lee," said Minnesota coach Dennis Green. "That would have tied it and we could have played with them all game. You can't give Dallas four turnovers in 30 minutes and hope to win.
"Yes, I'm worried about my job, shouldn't I be?"
"Yes, I guess you could say we turned it up at crunch time," said Dallas coach Barry Switzer.
